video.title: Bloodstained: Ritual of the Night (Zero Punctuation)

captions.text:
Ah, Castlevania, a series close to my heart
for being an excellent series of challenging

open-world gothic platformers, and for providing
an easy rhyme for Wrestlemania when I&#39;m in
a rap battle.

And no Castlevania is remembered more fondly
than Castlevania Symphony of the Night.
Why are you bringing that up, Yahtz?

The video title clearly states that this is
a review of Bloodstained: Ritual of the Night,

which is an entirely separate thing with a
whole two different words in the title.
Oh don&#39;t be coy.

You know damn well this is the Mighty No.
9 thing again where the original IP is being

held prisoner by a parent company who are
doing nothing but sitting on it letting off

the occasional fart, having tried and failed
to stick the series up a big hairy like God

of War but, so the original creator behind
the series&#39; success, in this case Koji Igarashi,

broke off and went to Kickstarter, saying
&quot;Hey, come and fund my new game, WINK.
It&#39;s a totally new IP, WINK.&quot;

And then of course it&#39;s the Castlevania Symphony
of the Night remake with a finger under its

nose going &quot;I can&#39;t be Castlevania, Castlevania
doesn&#39;t have a moustache.&quot;

So Bloodstained briefly ties itself in knots
coming up with all new lore to explain why

a magical demon hunter - or Shardbinder in
this case - needs to come fuck up a magically

conjured castle full of monsters that isn&#39;t
Dracula&#39;s castle even though Dracula is public

domain so surely it could&#39;ve been, and after
that things will quickly seem familiar.

Yahtzee, don&#39;t you go giving this game no
free ride just &#39;cos YOU like Symphony of the
Night, you fork-tongued sidewinder.

Don&#39;t worry, passing cowboy, if Bloodstained
were just Symphony with the serial numbers

filed off, which it certainly looks like at
times, I&#39;d&#39;ve had to dock points for it being

less innovative new work than masturbation
exercise, but actually Bloodstained is a supercut

of all the good ideas in Igarashi&#39;s later
Castlevanias as well.

So from Aria of Sorrow it takes the soul collecting
mechanic where every single monster grants
a unique power or buff.

In Aria this was the kind of genius idea that
was obvious in retrospect: most Castlevania

games have monster rosters you&#39;d struggle
to fit on an average CVS receipt in very small

writing and this gave us a gameplay reason
to catalogue them.

Later games tried and failed to improve on
it, the gylph absorbing in Order of Ecclesia

was just the same fucking thing with its arms
and legs cut off, so fuck it, here it is again.

And from Ecclesia Bloodstained takes the helping
out villagers sidequests and several of the

plot elements, such as a female main character
who somehow manages to be simultaneously under
and overdressed.

I remember the first time I saw Miriam, Bloodstained&#39;s
protagonist, my first thought was &quot;Are you
fucking serious?&quot;
Why&#39;s she wearing one third of a breastplate?

The devil horns, the rose tattoos, the puffball
miniskirt that&#39;s like one millimetre short

of putting camel toe on full display like
a frog&#39;s head peering over a log, the way

she constantly poses like Betty Boop trying
to stay upright in a strong wind, she looks

like someone opened one of those incredibly
pathetic anime girlfriend dress up simulators
and then sat on the keyboard.
And it doesn&#39;t stop there.

In Symphony of the Night, your equipment list
could SAY that Alucard is wearing a coal miner&#39;s

helmet and a handlebar moustache, but looking
at him in-game he&#39;d still be his normal devastatingly

handsome anime self &#39;cos it was all baked-in
sprites.

Well, with the wonderful march of technology,
Miriam can now be visibly wearing all those

ridiculous accessories and there are offically
no brakes on the looking completely stupid
train.

Kinda kills a dramatic cutscene when you rock
up with bunny ears and a piece of bog roll
sellotaped to your nose.

I think it&#39;s perfectly reasonable to not be
100% literal with the niceties of a game like

this, I mean, when I pause the game and eat
five curries in the middle of a tricky boss

fight, this is on the assumption that when
I unpause Miriam won&#39;t have a tummy ache and
basmati rice all down her front.

On the whole, though, I don&#39;t know how many
times I can rephrase &quot;if you liked Koji Igarashi&#39;s

Castlevania games you&#39;ll like the shit out
of this &#39;cos it&#39;s all of them smashed together
with a very poorly dressed lady on the front.&quot;

You go back and forth across not-Dracula&#39;s
castle in the usual way, growing in power

as you kill endless streams of classic Castlevania
monsters all holding their fingers under their
noses.
Sometimes the critical path is a bit obscure.

I&#39;m ashamed to admit I had to look up the
way forward more than once, but rest assured

I always made sure to compensate by punching
myself in the testicles.

&quot;Oh I see, I was supposed to get a water traversal
soul from this one random monster that only

appears in one room and doesn&#39;t even drop
it all the time, OOF!

Couldn&#39;t you even figure that out, you stupid,
swollen-testicled fuck?&quot;
But it was fairly smooth sailing on the whole.

The rest of my niggles are little niggles,
the least little niggle being that I find

the full 3d look to be kinda ugly in ways
that crafted 2D pixel art can never be, I&#39;ve

never seen a pixel art stone wall with slightly
misaligned and overstretched textures, or

one that mysteriously turns into a barcode
when a crack or blood splatter decal is applied
to it.

Also, I had recurring annoyances with the
interface.

Why does this game always find it so hard
to believe that I want to skip a fucking cutscene?

Why do I have to press the skip button, like,
five times?

This is my third attempt at this boss fight,
I have established to my satisfaction that
This Ends Now.

I don&#39;t wanna just skip the first bit of dialogue
and get to the little animation that precedes

the second and third bit of dialogue, I want
to skip the whole thing and get to the part

where I start hitting them with sharp objects
and the occasional magically-conjured pig.

Also, whenever I used the Shortcut ability
to switch to a normally unused but suddenly

necessary traversal power, the game would
unequip my weapon.

But I hesitate to mention that because it&#39;s
a bug.

And games being what they are these days it&#39;ll
probably get patched out soon in order to
make me look like a twat.
And for no other reason.
So that&#39;s the niggles.

Those aside, Bloodstained is the exceedingly
rare overfunded kickstarter project that delivers
on its promises.

It&#39;s exactly what you wanted, it&#39;s Symphony
of the Night again, but bigger and brought

up to date without changing the fundamental
things that you liked about it, albeit with

some portraits of very greasy people who ponied
up extra cash dotted around the map, the occasional

monster modelled after their pet dog and a
Special Thanks section in the credits that
goes on for three fucking hours.

So I hope Bloodstained realises what it has
done.

All we needed was a few more disappointing
fuckups.

A few more Mighty No. 9s, Yooka Laylees, Broken
Ages, and maybe we could&#39;ve all been completely
soured to the kickstarted retro callback.

&quot;Oh maybe it isn&#39;t healthy to never want to
leave our youthful comfort zones,&quot; we could&#39;ve
all said.

&quot;Maybe we should be open to new thoughts and
ideas, for just as the genepool requires variance,

so too does art need a diversity of new concepts
to avoid stagnation and producing nothing

but the cultural equivalent of harelips and
webbed toes.&quot;

And you&#39;ve fucked that up, Bloodstained, by
proving the system can actually work.

Now it&#39;s gonna be kickstarted remakes of Custer&#39;s
Revenge as far as the eye can see.

If you want a picture of the future, imagine
General Custer&#39;s lovingly rendered shiny bellend
slapping a human face, forever.
